conversations.content: How does the tax treatment of Berkshire's results compare to the S&P 500, and what impact does this have on performance in different market conditions?

The S&P 500 numbers are pre-tax, whereas Berkshire's numbers are after-tax. This means if we simply owned the S&P 500 and paid the appropriate taxes, our results would lag the S&P in good years but exceed it in bad years. Over time, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag.
What is the relationship between book value and intrinsic value at Berkshire, and how have they changed over the 40 years since you took over?

Book value and intrinsic value are related but distinct. Our book value has grown at a 21.9% annual rate over 40 years, from $19 to $55,824 per share. However, intrinsic value, which is what really counts, has grown even more. We've transformed from a struggling textile business to a diversified enterprise worth more than our book value, so our intrinsic value gain has somewhat exceeded the book value increase.
Why do you consider the yearly calculations of book value at Berkshire to be 'slightly understated' as a gauge for measuring the long-term rate of increase in intrinsic value?

I consider the yearly calculations of book value to be slightly understated because, while they provide a useful measure, they don't fully capture the complexities of our intrinsic value. It's like trying to measure the size of a room by just looking at the door - you get an idea, but not the whole picture.
How does the shift in the composition of Berkshire's net worth, with equity holdings now being less than 50%, affect your performance compared to the S&P 500 index?

Well, it's simple: with less of our net worth tied up in equities, the stock market's ups and downs affect us less. Think of it like a ship that's less exposed to the waves. In years when the market soars, we might underperform, and in years when it tanks, we might overperform. But at the end of the day, our long-term performance against the S&P is what really matters.
What approach do you recommend for individuals trying to time their participation in equities?
I advise them to be fearful when others are greedy and greedy only when others are fearful. It's a simple yet effective strategy that can help them make informed decisions.
What is the significance of MidAmerican Energy Holdings to Berkshire, and what are some of its notable operations?

MidAmerican Energy Holdings is a significant part of Berkshire, with us holding an 80.5% interest. It owns a variety of utility operations, including Yorkshire Electricity and Northern Electric, which is the third largest distributor of electricity in the U.K., as well as MidAmerican Energy, which serves nearly 700,000 electric customers in Iowa.
What lesson did you learn from the zinc recovery project, and how do you apply it to your investments and operations?

Well, I learned that it's crucial to stick with simple propositions. When you have multiple variables that need to break in your favor, the chances of success decrease dramatically. In the case of the zinc project, we solved most of the problems, but one proved insurmountable. It's like a chain - it's only as strong as its weakest link. So, we look for investments and operations where the variables are fewer and more controllable. It's just common sense, but it's easy to get caught up in the excitement of a potential opportunity and overlook the complexities.
How many brokers do you employ through your 17 brokerage firms, and in how many states do they operate?

We employ more than 18,000 brokers through our 17 brokerage firms, and they operate in 18 states. It's a significant presence, and we're proud to have such a large and talented team serving our clients across the country.
What factors contribute to the high lifetime cost of adding a new employee, according to the text?

Well, it's not just the salary. When you factor in raises, benefits, and other expenses, the cost adds up quickly. As the text says, 'more people, more toilet paper' - it's a humorous way of looking at it, but it's true. All those extras can turn a seemingly small addition into a $3 million decision over time.
What is Don Wurster's approach to managing NICO, and how does it relate to the current market conditions?

Don's approach is to be disciplined and patient, much like a baseball player who'd rather take a walk than swing at a bad pitch. He's not chasing growth for its own sake, especially when insurance prices are falling. In fact, as NICO's volume declines, I'll be applauding him even more - he's making smart, long-term decisions that will pay off in the end, like amassing $950 million of negative-cost float.
What is the significance of Don amassing $950 million of float at NICO, and how will its volume be affected by falling insurance prices?

The $950 million of float at NICO is significant because it's likely to be the negative-cost kind, meaning it will ultimately benefit our business. As for the volume, it will soon decline very significantly due to falling insurance prices, but Charlie and I will actually applaud Don more loudly as this happens.
How did State Farm manage to capture about 25% of the personal lines business, and what was the key to its success?

State Farm's success can be attributed to its low-cost structure, which was achieved by employing a captive agency force. This approach kept its acquisition costs lower than those of the traditional bureau insurers, allowing State Farm to offer competitive prices and eventually outdistance its competitors.
What was the state of GEICO in 1976 and how did Jack Byrne contribute to its recovery?

In 1976, GEICO was on the brink of failure due to under-reserving for losses and inadequate pricing. Jack Byrne, who joined as CEO, made heroic efforts to save the company, including implementing major price increases. Though this led to a loss of policyholders, his actions were crucial in preventing the company's collapse.
How has GEICO performed under Tony Nicely's leadership, and what benefits has it delivered to its constituents?

Under Tony Nicely's leadership, GEICO has seen significant growth and profitability. By 2005, we expect to secure a 6% market share. More importantly, GEICO has delivered major benefits to all its constituents: our customers saved around $1 billion in 2004, our associates earned a $191 million profit-sharing bonus, and as the owner, we've enjoyed excellent financial returns.
What is the largest insured loss to date, and how does it compare to the potential loss of a mega-catastrophe?

The largest insured loss to date is the World Trade Center disaster, which cost the insurance industry an estimated $35 billion. However, I believe a $100 billion event, or even a larger catastrophe, remains a possibility if a particularly severe earthquake or hurricane hits just the wrong place.
How would Berkshire's financials be affected if a $100 billion industry loss were to occur?

If a $100 billion industry loss were to occur, our share of the loss would probably be 3% to 5%. But I'm confident that earnings from our investments and other businesses would comfortably exceed that cost, so when 'the day after' arrives, Berkshire's checks will clear.
What challenges have you faced in winding down Gen Re Securities, and how many contracts were still outstanding at the end of the year?

Well, getting out of the derivative operation has been easier said than done, kind of like trying to leave a bad habit behind. We started this process three years ago, but as of the end of the year, we still had 2,890 contracts outstanding, down from a peak of 23,218. It's a slow and tricky process, especially when you're dealing with instruments that are supposed to be liquid but don't always behave that way.

You mention that rapid growth can sometimes mask underlying problems in financial institutions. Can you elaborate on what you mean by this, and how does it relate to the real test of a derivatives operation's earning power?

Think of it like a tide coming in - it can make everyone look like a great swimmer. But when the tide goes out, you find out who's been swimming naked, meaning who's been hiding problems. For a derivatives operation, the real test isn't when it's growing rapidly, because that can cover up a lot of sins. The real test is when it's operating in a no-growth mode, over an extended period. That's when you see what it's truly capable of earning, without the mask of rapid expansion.
What was your initial opinion about opening the first Las Vegas store, and how did it perform?

I have to admit, I thought opening the first Las Vegas store was a mistake. I was concerned that our closed-on-Sunday policy would be a turn-off for customers who were used to shopping seven days a week. But, as it often does, the market proved me wrong. The store immediately became our number one unit, which was a resounding answer to my doubts.
How did the second Las Vegas store perform, despite your initial concerns about cannibalizing sales from the first store?

Well, I was wrong again. The second Las Vegas store not only didn't cannibalize sales from the first store, but both stores are now doing about 26% more volume than any other store in the chain. They're consistently showing large year-over-year gains, which is a great testament to the team's ability to execute and prove me wrong - again.
How do you typically find out about Lou's investment transactions?

I typically learn of Lou's transactions about ten days after the end of each month. Charlie and I give him a lot of autonomy, just like our operating managers, so I don't get informed about his decisions beforehand.
Why did Berkshire start investing in foreign currencies in 2002?

We started investing in foreign currencies because we believe our country's trade policies will put pressure on the dollar for many years to come. It's not that I doubt America's strength - we're the richest country in the world with a fantastic economy - but our trade practices are a concern for the dollar's value.
What is your view on true trade, which involves the exchange of goods and services with other countries?
I believe true trade is enormously beneficial for both the US and other countries. In fact, last year we had $1.15 trillion of such honest-to-God trade, and I think the more of this, the better.
What happens as a result of the US purchasing a significant amount of goods and services from the rest of the world without reciprocation?

The balancing item to this one-way pseudo-trade is a transfer of wealth from the US to the rest of the world. In other words, when we buy $618 billion more from other countries than they buy from us, it means we're essentially transferring wealth to them.
Why do you think the world won't tolerate the U.S. spendthrift behavior indefinitely?

Well, it's just common sense - no one likes a freeloader, and the world knows we're living beyond our means. Just like an individual, a country can't keep spending more than it earns without eventually facing the music. The world's patience won't last forever, and I think they'll eventually call us on it.
What's your recommendation for people who want to stay informed about trade and currency matters?

If you want to stay up-to-date on trade and currency, I highly recommend reading The Financial Times. Their reporting and commentary are top-notch, and they've been the go-to source for international financial news for a long time. They've even got an excellent American edition now, so it's easy to stay informed.

Why do you think following the conventional approach of leaving all of Berkshire's assets in dollars, even if they decline in value, would not draw criticism, while your current foreign-exchange commitment might?

Well, as I said, it's a bit like the lemming situation. If everyone else is doing something, even if it's not the best approach, it's harder to criticize an individual for following the crowd. In this case, if we just stuck with dollars and didn't try to manage our currency risk, we'd be doing what a lot of others do, and our mistake would be less visible. But by taking a different path, we're more likely to be noticed and criticized if we're wrong.
What inspired universities to start sending their students to visit you in Omaha, and which universities will be visiting this year?

It all started when Al Auxier, a professor from the University of Tennessee, brought his finance students to Omaha for a tour and Q&A session. They were involved in our acquisition of Clayton Homes, and I think they had a pretty positive experience. Word must have gotten around, because now we've got a whole list of universities sending their students to visit us. This year, we'll be hosting classes from schools like Chicago, Dartmouth, Stanford, and many more - a total of 20 universities, ranging in size from 30 to 100 students.
What are the two post-bubble governance reforms that you've found particularly useful at Berkshire?

I've found two reforms to be especially useful: regular meetings of directors without the CEO present, which helps ensure that dubious plans get thoroughly examined, and the 'whistleblower line,' which allows employees to report issues to me and the audit committee without fear of reprisal.
How do you think the implementation of a whistleblower line earlier on would have impacted Berkshire's value?

I believe Berkshire would be more valuable today if I had put in a whistleblower line decades ago. It's helped me catch important problems at our subsidiaries that I otherwise would have missed, and I think it would have made a significant difference over time.
Why do you often get assigned to the audit committee?

Well, it's quite simple really. Since directors must be assigned to one committee or another, and no CEO wants me on their compensation committee, I usually end up on the audit committee. I guess you could say I'm not their first choice for deciding on their pay!
How do you respond to concerns about your independence on the board due to Berkshire's business dealings with Coke?

I think it's pretty straightforward. Just because Berkshire's companies, like McLane and Dairy Queen, buy a lot of Coke products, it doesn't mean I'm not independent. My focus is on the well-being of Coke's shareholders, and with Berkshire holding $8 billion of Coke stock, that's a pretty strong incentive for me to make decisions in their best interest. As the saying goes, 'where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.'
What is your view on how director independence is affected by the fees they receive for board service?

In my view, directors who receive a significant fraction of their annual income from board fees are likely to be the least independent. It's just human nature - they wouldn't want to rock the boat and risk losing their livelihood. It's ironic that these are often the ones classified as 'independent'.
Can you describe the biblical standard you mentioned in relation to Berkshire's board of directors?

The biblical standard I mentioned refers to the idea that 'where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.' At Berkshire, our board members have a significant amount of their own 'treasure' - at least $4 million in stock - invested in the company. This aligns their interests with those of our shareholders, and I believe it makes a big difference in their decision-making.
What was unusual about the non-management directors' behavior regarding the acquisition proposal and their own stock purchases?

Well, it's quite simple really. These directors didn't want shareholders to have the opportunity to consider an acquisition offer, even though they themselves had passed on buying the stock at a much lower price. It's a bit like turning down a steak dinner at $10 and then not wanting to let others know about a $20 offer for the same steak.
How might the potential acquisition have affected the non-management directors financially?

If the deal had gone through, those directors would have lost their annual board and committee fees, which were around $100,000. That's a significant amount of money, and it's clear that for some of them, this 'treasure' was a big part of their income.
